Problem:
Imagine we are studying a linear system of differential equations represented by \\(\\dot{x} = Mx\\), where M is a constant coefficient matrix. To examine the behavior under different transformations, we introduce the function \\( g(x) = x^T Qx \\), a quadratic form where Q is a symmetric constant matrix.

If we introduce a new transformation \\( h(x) = P x \\) at a specific time \\( t_1 \\), which linearly alters the system state, will the state at \\( x(T) \\) for T > t_1 only rely on M and not on Q or P?
Explanation: The intervention using \\( h(x) = P x \\) injects a new dynamic, altering the linear pathway of the system depending on matrix P. The new trajectory from \\( t_1 \\) to T will thus be influenced by how P interacts with M and potentially Q if any quadratic operations remain effective. As such, the final state at T will depend on matrices P, Q, and M.
